substances.name: DMAA
substances.legalStatusDetails: Banned as unsafe food additive (April 2013). Prohibited by WADA since 2010.

healthRisks.description: 86 reports of illnesses and deaths (FDA database), including at least 5 fatalities directly attributed.
Case reports of hemorrhagic stroke in young athletes.

substances.description: DMAA (1,3-dimethylamylamine) is a synthetic stimulant originally developed as a nasal decongestant. It gained popularity in pre-workout supplements and weight loss products between 2005-2013 but has been banned due to serious cardiovascular risks including deaths.
substances.mechanism: Norepinephrine releasing agent causing vasoconstriction, elevated blood pressure and heart rate. Increases CNS stimulation and peripheral vasoconstriction.
substances.history: Originally patented by Eli Lilly in 1944 as a nasal decongestant. Resurfaced in supplements around 2006 marketed as 'geranium extract' despite being synthetic. Found in pre-workout supplements until FDA ban.
substances.whyBanned: Unacceptable risk of serious cardiovascular events even at recommended doses. Benefits do not outweigh risks. 5 deaths directly attributed to DMAA use.
substances.metaTitle: DMAA (1,3-DMAA) - Why It's Banned & Safe Alternatives | Blush & Breathe
substances.metaDescription: Learn why DMAA was banned by the FDA after 5 deaths, its health risks including stroke and heart attack, and discover safe legal alternatives for pre-workout energy.

substances.name: Phenibut
substances.legalStatusDetails: Banned as dietary supplement ingredient (April 2019). Schedule II in Alabama.

healthRisks.description: 1,320 poison center cases reported (2009-2019), sharp increase 2015-2019. 3 deaths, 80 comas.
sources: American Association of Poison Control Centers

healthRisks.description: Severe withdrawal syndrome similar to alcohol withdrawal - can be life-threatening.

substances.description: Phenibut is a GABA analogue that binds to GABA-B receptors, producing anxiolytic and sedative effects similar to GHB. Marketed as a nootropic/anxiety reliever but has high abuse potential with severe, potentially life-threatening withdrawal syndrome.
substances.mechanism: Binds to GABA-B receptors, producing anxiolytic and sedative effects similar to GHB. Crosses blood-brain barrier efficiently. Also has some GABA-A activity at higher doses.
substances.history: Developed in the Soviet Union in the 1960s for cosmonauts to manage stress and anxiety. Never approved for medical use in the USA. Gained popularity as a nootropic/supplement in the 2010s.
substances.whyBanned: FDA determined risk of severe withdrawal, addiction, and overdose outweighs claimed benefits. Not proven effective for stated uses. Withdrawal can cause seizures and death.
substances.metaTitle: Phenibut - Why It's Banned, Withdrawal Dangers & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Phenibut was banned by the FDA, the severe withdrawal syndrome risks, and discover safe legal alternatives for anxiety and relaxation.

substances.name: Kratom
substances.legalStatusDetails: Under FDA Import Alert 54-15. Illegal in 7 states. Age/testing restrictions in others.

stateRestrictions.Texas: Synthetic kratom banned, strict alkaloid limits

healthRisks.description: 199 people infected in 2018 Salmonella outbreak. Products often contaminated with bacteria, heavy metals.

substances.description: Kratom is a plant from Southeast Asia containing alkaloids that act on opioid receptors. Marketed as a 'natural herbal supplement' but has opioid-like effects with overdose risk, withdrawal syndrome, and significant contamination issues.
substances.mechanism: Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine act on mu-opioid receptors (similar to opioids). Also has NMDA antagonism. Effects are dose-dependent: stimulant at low doses, sedative at high doses.
substances.history: Traditional use in Southeast Asia for centuries. Gained popularity in the US in the 2010s as an alternative to opioids. Multiple contamination outbreaks and deaths led to increased regulation.
substances.whyBanned: Opioid-like effects with overdose risk, contamination issues, withdrawal syndrome, and lack of quality control. FDA cannot ensure safety of kratom products.
substances.metaTitle: Kratom - Legal Status, Overdose Risks & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn about Kratom's legal status (banned in 7 states), opioid-like risks, 91 deaths, and discover safe legal alternatives for energy and relaxation.

substances.name: SARMs (Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Unapproved drugs - cannot be sold as dietary supplements. Felony charges for distribution.

stateRestrictions.Military: ALL SARMs on DOD Prohibited List

healthRisks.description: Multiple felony convictions for SARM distribution (2024-2025). Criminal risk to suppliers AND users.
Testosterone suppression requiring Post-Cycle Therapy. Unknown long-term effects.

substances.description: SARMs are synthetic drugs that bind to androgen receptors, claiming to build muscle selectively. They are unapproved drugs with unknown long-term risks, often contaminated or mislabeled, and carry serious legal consequences.
substances.mechanism: Bind to androgen receptors in muscle tissue, stimulating anabolic (muscle-building) effects. Claimed to be selective for muscle vs. prostate, but this selectivity is not proven in humans.
substances.history: Developed by pharmaceutical companies in the 1990s for muscle wasting diseases. None have been FDA approved. Proliferated in the supplement industry as 'research chemicals' to skirt regulations.
substances.whyBanned: Unapproved drugs with unknown long-term risks. FDA cannot ensure safety. Products often contaminated or mislabeled. Active criminal enforcement.
substances.metaTitle: SARMs - Why They're Illegal, Health Risks & Legal Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why SARMs are illegal unapproved drugs, the criminal penalties, health risks, and discover safe legal alternatives for muscle building.

substances.name: Ephedrine
substances.legalStatusDetails: Banned as dietary supplement ingredient since 2004. Landmark FDA ban case.

healthRisks.description: 155 deaths attributed to ephedra products (FDA count, 1995-2004). 10,000+ adverse event reports.
Heart attacks, strokes, arrhythmias, hypertensive crisis documented.

substances.description: Ephedrine is a sympathomimetic alkaloid that was widely used in weight loss and energy supplements until banned in 2004 after causing 155 deaths. This landmark case established modern FDA supplement oversight.
substances.mechanism: Alpha and beta-adrenergic agonist. Stimulates heart rate, blood pressure, and thermogenesis. Similar to adrenaline in effects.
substances.history: Used in traditional Chinese medicine for thousands of years. Became popular in US supplements in the 1990s. FDA banned after documenting 155 deaths. This case drove development of modern supplement regulations.
substances.whyBanned: Unacceptable cardiovascular risk. Risk-benefit analysis showed benefits do not justify mortality risk. 155 deaths documented before ban.
substances.metaTitle: Ephedrine (Ephedra) - Why It's Banned, 155 Deaths & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Ephedrine was banned after 155 deaths, its dangerous cardiovascular effects, and discover safe legal alternatives for weight loss and energy.

substances.name: Clenbuterol
substances.legalStatusDetails: NOT approved for human use in USA. Approved only for veterinary use (horses).

healthRisks.description: Cardiac hypertrophy, arrhythmia, electrolyte imbalances. Limited human safety data.

substances.description: Clenbuterol is a beta-2 agonist approved only for veterinary use in horses. It is used illegally in bodybuilding for fat loss and muscle preservation. Not studied extensively in humans.
substances.mechanism: Beta-2 agonist - increases metabolism and fat mobilization. Also increases muscle protein synthesis. Causes cardiac hypertrophy with chronic use.
substances.history: Developed as a bronchodilator. Approved for veterinary use in some countries. Used in bodybuilding communities since the 1980s. Food contamination incidents in Europe (2013).
substances.whyBanned: Not approved for human use. Veterinary drug only. Cardiovascular risks exceed any potential benefits. No human safety data.
substances.metaTitle: Clenbuterol - Why It's Illegal for Humans & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Clenbuterol is only approved for horses, the cardiovascular dangers, and discover safe legal alternatives for fat loss.

substances.name: Cardarine (GW501516)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Never FDA approved. Development abandoned due to cancer risk at ALL tested doses.

healthRisks.description: CANCER RISK - Caused multiple cancer types in animal studies at ALL tested doses. Development abandoned by GSK.

contraindications: Everyone - not safe for human use
substances.description: Cardarine (GW501516) is a PPAR delta agonist that was abandoned during drug development after causing cancer in animal studies at ALL tested doses. One of the most dangerous compounds still sold online.
substances.mechanism: Activates PPAR delta, increases fatty acid oxidation and endurance capacity. Also promotes cancer cell growth in multiple organ systems.
substances.history: Developed by GlaxoSmithKline for metabolic diseases. Development abandoned after 2-year animal studies showed cancer at all doses. Still sold illegally online as 'research chemical'.
substances.whyBanned: Cancer risk at ALL tested doses in animal models. Development abandoned by manufacturer due to unacceptable cancer risk. Never safe for human use.
substances.metaTitle: Cardarine (GW501516) - Cancer Risk Warning & Safe Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: CRITICAL WARNING: Cardarine caused cancer at ALL doses in studies. Learn why GSK abandoned it and discover safe legal alternatives for endurance.

substances.name: Nandrolone (Deca-Durabolin)
substances.legalStatusDetails: Schedule III controlled substance. Illegal without prescription. Felony possession.

healthRisks.description: Illegal possession is a felony. Most supply is from black market/counterfeits.
Testosterone suppression, testicular atrophy, requires PCT. Virilization in women.

substances.description: Nandrolone is an anabolic androgenic steroid classified as a Schedule III controlled substance. Illegal possession is a felony. Most gym supply is from black market with unknown purity.
substances.mechanism: Synthetic androgen. Binds to androgen receptors, stimulating protein synthesis and muscle growth. Suppresses natural testosterone production.
substances.history: Developed in the 1950s for medical use. Classified as Schedule III controlled substance under the Anabolic Steroid Control Act. Still prescribed rarely for anemia and wasting diseases.
substances.whyBanned: Controlled substance with abuse potential and significant health risks. Illegal without prescription. Black market products often contaminated.
substances.metaTitle: Nandrolone (Deca) - Schedule III Controlled Substance & Alternatives
substances.metaDescription: Learn why Nandrolone is a Schedule III controlled substance (felony possession), health risks, and discover safe legal alternatives for muscle building.
